ETYMOLOGY: From Old English ceorfan 'to cut, cut out, carve, engrave', from Proto-Germanic *kerfan. Related to German kerben 'to notch'.

MEANINGS.POS_TIP: transitive verb: a verb that requires one or more objects
MEANINGS.DEF_EN: To cut a solid material, especially wood or stone, in order to produce an object or design.
MEANINGS.DEF_ZH: 雕刻；刻画 (用坚硬的材料，尤其是木头或石头，制作物体或图案)
MEANINGS.SENT_EN: He likes to carve animals out of wood.
MEANINGS.SENT_ZH: 他喜欢用木头雕刻动物。

MEANINGS.POS_TIP: transitive verb: a verb that requires one or more objects
MEANINGS.DEF_EN: To cut cooked meat into slices for eating.
MEANINGS.DEF_ZH: 切（熟肉） (将煮熟的肉切成片)
MEANINGS.SENT_EN: My dad always carves the turkey at Thanksgiving.
MEANINGS.SENT_ZH: 我爸爸总是在感恩节切火鸡。

MEANINGS.POS_TIP: transitive verb with an adverb particle
MEANINGS.DEF_EN: To create or obtain something for oneself through effort, especially a position or a reputation.
MEANINGS.DEF_ZH: 开创；奠定；争取到 (通过努力为自己创造或获得某物，特别是职位或声誉)
MEANINGS.SENT_EN: She managed to carve out a successful career for herself.
MEANINGS.SENT_ZH: 她成功地为自己开创了一番事业。

MEANINGS.PATTERN: carve [sth] into [sth else] | carve [sth] on [sth else]
MEANINGS.POS_TIP: transitive verb followed by a preposition
MEANINGS.DEF_EN: To cut words or designs into the surface of something.
MEANINGS.DEF_ZH: 刻入；雕刻 (将文字或图案刻入某物的表面)
MEANINGS.SENT_EN: He carved their initials into the old oak tree.
MEANINGS.SENT_ZH: 他把他们的名字首字母刻在了那棵老橡树上。
